instruction: How does the combination of terahertz spectroscopy and LS-SVM compare to traditional methods for quantitatively analyzing benzoic acid additive in wheat flour?
Output:
The combination of terahertz spectroscopy and LS-SVM (least square support vector machine) is shown to be more effective than traditional methods, such as multiple linear regressions (MLR) and partial least square (PLS) regression, for quantitatively analyzing benzoic acid (BA) additive in wheat flour. 

The LS-SVM model, when combined with terahertz spectroscopy, demonstrated a high correlation coefficient of prediction (R-p) of 0.994 and a low root mean square error of prediction (RMSEP) of 0.12%. This indicates that the LS-SVM model is able to accurately predict the concentration of BA additive in wheat flour.

In comparison, MLR and PLS models were also used in the investigation, but the LS-SVM model outperformed them in terms of predictive ability. This suggests that the combination of terahertz spectroscopy and LS-SVM is a more effective tool for quality control and quantitative analysis of BA additive in wheat flour.
